posts.name: Eren
posts.cooked: Hello. I’m a member of a Turkish FRC Team. While visiting the states, I ordered an Orange Pi 5 Plus 8gb model on amazon for our team this year. I got my hands on it just now, and I’ve been sent the Ultra 8gb model . I’m a bit frustrated as the ultra is a bit cheaper. I ordered the 5 plus, knowing it was supported by Photonvision. Since I don’t see any images on the github for the 5 ultra, is this model supported by photonvision? Apparently I can return the Orange Pi at a nearby wholefoods for a refund, but the extra that I paid is still cheaper than what I would have paid back in Turkey, so I’m unsure wether to keep it or not, or wether it is possible if I can just be refunded the price gap between the two models. Looking for advice, thanks in advance.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I would read this.  It has what will work with Photonvision:

PhotonVision Welcome to the official documentation of PhotonVision! PhotonVision is the free, fast, and easy-to-use vision processing solution for the FIRST Robotics Competition. PhotonVision is de...

Personally, I would keep it.  Use is for a testbed for future systems for vision.  Orange pi use to be the “standard” for Photonvision…now it isn’t.  I am not sure what happened.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
When I was looking awhile back…OrangePi was predominately mentioned above RasPi.  Now it looks like it is just barely mentioned.  It is only mentioned under storage media and the performance matrix.  It use to be under Choosing a Co Processor.  Now it isn’t mentioned.

I am not doubting your words…I am just looking at the above mentioned document page.  That is the current page…and as I don’t have the one available from when I last looked…I cannot prove my claims.

I know this as I was looking at doing Photonvision awhile back for our team.  Started investigating cost and talking with our coders, looking at cameras we would need…for the best performance.

This is under the Choosing a Co processor section:

Choosing a Coprocessor Minimum System Requirements

Ubuntu 22.04 LTS or Windows 10/11*

Ubuntu 22.04 LTS or Windows 10/11*

We don’t recommend using Windows for anything except testing out the system on a local machine.*

CPU: ARM Cortex-A53 (the CPU on Raspberry Pi 3) or better*

CPU: ARM Cortex-A53 (the CPU on Raspberry Pi 3) or better*

At least 8GB of storage*

At least 8GB of storage*

2GB of RAM*

2GB of RAM*

PhotonVision isn’t very RAM intensive, but you’ll need at least 2GB to run the OS and PhotonVision.*

The following IO:*

The following IO:*

At least 1 USB or MIPI-CSI port for the camera*

Note that we only support using the Raspberry Pi’s MIPI-CSI port, other MIPI-CSI ports from other coprocessors will probably not work.*

  *Ethernet port for networking*

Note these are bare minimums. Most high-performance vision processing will require higher specs.

Nothing about OrangePi.  It use to state OrangePi5 then RasPi(3?).

This is all I am saying.

Quick question: Why is the orange pi 5+ not officially recommended? On the npu part of the docs, it says it is supported. I have also had great results testing it, and it is not that much more expensive while having more usb ports and better performance.

posts.name: Matthew L

The SOC is different, rk3588 on 5+ vs rk3588 S on 5, and it has slightly better performance, from benchmarks I’ve seen online.

posts.cooked: Oh ok that makes sense. Our team just bought 5+'s to test multiple cameras with the extra USB port, and see if there are any performance improvements/reductions. It was only ~$30 CAD(~$21.90 USD) more, so not that a big of a deal if there is no performance improvement.

posts.name: Craig Schardt
posts.cooked:
As someone who has helped maintain and test the PhotonVision images for the last couple years, I’d like to share some more detail around the Orange Pi 5 images.

The Orange Pi 5 is currently one of the most powerful SBCs available. It is based on the RK3588(S) which has an 8-core CPU (4xA55 + 4xA76) and a built-in NPU for machine-learning tasks (other SBCs require an add-on NPU for ML). This makes it very attractive for FRC vision processing since it works well for both April Tag recognition and localization and for Machine Learning-based object detection.

The base Orange Pi 5 with 4GB of RAM offers everything needed to run PhotonVision. Several PhotonVision developers have the base OPi5 and that is typically the only version used for testing. There are many other versions of the OPi5 including the Plus, Max, Pro, B, and Ultra, but the differences are insignificant for running PhotonVision, so the recommendation is to stick with the least expensive and most well-tested board.

Purchasing a more expensive board or one with more RAM will not get you any better performance with PhotonVision. As grahamsh stated, the RK3588 and RK3588S have the same CPU cores, clock speed, GPU, and NPU, so there is no difference when running PhotonVision. PhotonVision + the OS runs in < 1GB of RAM and more memory doesn’t increase performance.

An argument could be made for more USB ports to support for more cameras. If they are USB 2.0 though, bandwidth limitations will limit performance when running more than 2-3 cameras. You can work around the bandwidth limit by running the cameras at lower resolution and/or frame rate, or by using USB 3.0 cameras, but then you’ll be limited by CPU performance for detecting April Tags, especially on higher-resolution images. The exact limits depend on several settings, but I’ve been able to get > 30 fps from 2 cameras at 720p on one OPi 5.

The OPi 5 images are based on the Ubuntu-rockchip community project images. There is currently no OPi 5 Ultra image available, so, practically speaking, there is no source image for PhotonVision to use. From a project perspective, contributors have also questioned the benefit of providing images for so many different flavors of OPi5. Small differences between the boards can create extra work for the volunteer contributors, the images require resources and time to test, and the proliferation of images creates confusion for teams interested in using PhotonVision. The compromise has been to continue to provide the images that have already been created, but avoid creating any more for new OPi5 variants. Photonvision can also be installed on most boards that run a recent Debian-based distributions via the install script , which provides a solution for boards like the OPi5 Ultra, as was mentioned earlier in this thread.

I hope this helps shed some light on what has been a point of confusion for several teams looking to adopt PhotonVision.

link_counts.title: Other Debian-Based Co-Processor Installation - PhotonVision Docs
GitHub - Joshua-Riek/ubuntu-rockchip: Ubuntu for Rockchip RK35XX Devices
